DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Japanese Vice Finance Minister for International Affairs Asakawa said Japan will closely watch whether recent Yen movement will be speculative. (Newswires)

New Zealand Food Price Index (Jan) 1.2% (Prev. -0.8%). (Newswires)


NORTH AMERICA

Fed's Powell stated that the Fed are in the process of gradually normalising rates and the Fed is to 'remain alert' to financial stability risks. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester stated that she supports rate increases at a pace similar to last year, but will watch the impact of tax and other fiscal policy changes. She later said upside risks to the forecast more salient than they have been for some time. Furthermore, there were also reports that Mester is among the candidates for Fed Vice Chair. (Newswires/WSJ)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said NAFTA progress is being made especially with Mexico, while there were also comments from Canada’s Chief NAFTA Negotiator who stated they are conscious the US could implement a NAFTA pull out but noted Canada is ready for that. (Newswires)


UK / EU

UK CPI MM (Jan) -0.5% vs. Exp. -0.6% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
UK CPI YY (Jan) 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 3.0%)
UK Core CPI MM (Jan) -0.8% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. 0.3%)
UK Core CPI YY (Jan) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)

ECB's Weidmann said there is no need to go beyond September in regards to QE purchases. (Newswires)

SPD’s Schulz said he is quitting his role of party chairman with immediate effect, while Andrea Nahles has been unanimously backed to succeed him. (Newswires)


FX

The USD continued to give back the gains seen last week, amid the apparent risk-off flows, and the DXY trades 0.5% softer heading into APAC trade, having slipped through 90. JPY was a notable gainer, helped along by the greenback weakness as well as overnight headlines by Japan PM Abe suggesting that he has a “blank slate” for choosing the next BOJ governor (hinting that Kuroda’s reappointment isn’t a done-deal). Other havens were also bid, though gold price action is struggling with the $1330 level. The EUR has made its way back up to the 1.2350 level. GBP jumped after CPI data vindicated the BOE’s recent hawkishness, though cable struggled to remain above the 1.39 handle. EMFX couldn’t take advantage of USD weakness, though ZAR trades will be keeping an ear out for newsflow tomorrow morning following Zuma’s announcement on his Presidency after the ANC demanded he step down.
 

COMMODITIES

US API weekly crude stocks (5 Feb, w/e) 3.947M vs. Exp. 2.800M (Prev. -1.05M). (Newswires)

IEA have upgraded their forecast for global oil demand growth to 1.4mln bpd in 2018 from 1.3mln, however they say Non-OPEC supply, led by US, which is likely to grow more than demand in 2018. Global oil supply fell to 97.7mln in January, although is up 1.3mln bpd Y/Y. (Newswires)

Kremlin said Russia remains committed to the OPEC production cuts. Russian Energy Minister Novak then stated that OPEC and Non-OPEC allies need to act very cautiously and avoid knee-jerk reactions in respect of new decisions. Later on he stated oil inventories are shrinking despite rising production in US, 2018 average oil price is seen closer to USD 60/bbl. (Newswires)

Iraq oil minister stated that there is no current discussion over exiting supply cut agreement and any discussion on supply cut agreements can wait until December. (Newswires)

Libya National Oil Company (NOC) reports Zawiya oil field is operating at 70% capacity. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea does not intend to give up its weapons in negotiations, according to reports. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Although stocks started cash trade on the back foot, comments by new Fed Chair Powell lent support to the equity complex, after he stated that the Fed are in the process of gradually normalising rates and the Fed will 'remain alert' to financial stability risks. In afternoon trade, major indices pared back losses on little news, with some traders talking about technical levels (100d MA) playing a role. In sector specific news, energy was tracking crude weakness. Healthcare suffered after reports that Amazon was set to push into the sector, as well as the US FTC’s complaint against dental firms weighing on some name. S&P 500 +0.26% at 2663, Nasdaq +0.46 at 6554, and DJIA Up 0.16% at 24640

Top sectors: Consumer Cyclicals +0.70%, Consumer Non-Cyclicals +0.60% and Financials +0.50%
Bottom sectors: Energy -0.45%, Materials -0.18% and Healthcare +0.03%

USTs were mixed, though yields have remained in their recent range, with 10-year lingering around the 2.85% mark. Ahead of tomorrow’s CPI data, the odds of a March hike are just shy of 80%. After January’s nonfarm payroll data showed wage inflation rising above expectations, attention will be on the January CPI data for confirmation of the trend in price pressures. In wake of the NFP data, markets aggressively repriced their expectations for Fed rates hikes in 2018 as real yields rose. Some suggest that a disappointing print raises the potential of a correction of that pricing, while a beat may give credence to the notion that the Fed may lift rates four times this year. 10 year. T-note futures settle 3+ ticks higher at 121-00.

US MARKET WRAP: Powell says Fed ‘alert’ to financial stability risks; tomorrow’s US CPI data eyed
content:
EQUITIES: S&P 500 +0.26% at 2663, Nasdaq +0.46 at 6554, and DJIA Up 0.16% at 24640

Top sectors: Consumer Cyclicals +0.70%, Consumer Non-Cyclicals +0.60% and Financials +0.50%

Bottom sectors: Energy -0.45%, Materials -0.18% and Healthcare +0.03%

Although stocks started cash trade on the back foot, comments by new Fed Chair Powell lent support to the equity complex, after he stated that the Fed are in the process of gradually normalising rates and the Fed will 'remain alert' to financial stability risks. In afternoon trade, major indices pared back losses on little news, with some traders talking about technical levels (100d MA) playing a role. In sector specific news, energy was tracking crude weakness. Healthcare suffered after reports that Amazon was set to push into the sector, as well as the US FTC’s complaint against dental firms weighing on some names.

 

TREASURIES:  10 year T-note futures settle 3+ ticks higher at 121-00

USTs are mixed, though yields have remained in their recent range, with 10-year lingering around the 2.85% mark. Ahead of tomorrow’s CPI data, the odds of a March hike are just shy of 80%. After January’s nonfarm payroll data showed wage inflation rising above expectations, attention will be on the January CPI data for confirmation of the trend in price pressures. In wake of the NFP data, markets aggressively repriced their expectations for Fed rates hikes in 2018 as real yields rose. Some suggest that a disappointing print raises the potential of a correction of that pricing, while a beat may give credence to the notion that the Fed may lift rates four times this year.

 

FOREX: DXY trades 0.5% lower heading into APAC trade.

The USD continued to give back the gains seen last week, amid the apparent risk-off flows, and the DXY trades 0.5% softer heading into APAC trade, having slipped through 90. JPY was a notable gainer, helped along by the greenback weakness as well as overnight headlines by Japan PM Abe suggesting that he has a “blank slate” for choosing the next BOJ governor (hinting that Kuroda’s reappointment isn’t a done-deal). Other havens were also bid, though gold price action is struggling with the $1330 level. The EUR has made its way back up to the 1.2350 level. GBP jumped after CPI data vindicated the BOE’s recent hawkishness, though cable struggled to remain above the 1.39 handle. EMFX couldn’t take advantage of USD weakness, though ZAR trades will be keeping an ear out for newsflow tomorrow morning following Zuma’s announcement on his Presidency after the ANC demanded he step down.

 

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 10 cents lower at USD 59.19 per barrel; Brent futures settle 13 cents higher at USD 62.72 per barrel

Like the OPEC and EIA reports earlier in the week, there wasn’t much for oil bulls to latch onto in the IEA’s monthly report; the organisation forecast global supply will outstrip demand in 2018, raising its demand growth forecast by 1.4mln barrels per day. Crude was mixed, generally toying around the neutral line ahead of the API inventory data, due for release aftermarket.  This week, analysts expect crude stocks to build by 2.8mln barrels, Cushing is expected to draw by 2.5mln, distillates are seen drawing by 1.1mln and gasoline stocks are forecast to build 1.2mln.

subject: FX Daily Wrap: Dollar Index finds some traction ahead of 89.500 level
content: A better 2nd half (so far) for the Greenback amidst hawkish commentary from Fed’s Mester and reassuring rhetoric from new Chair Powell. However, the Usd had already managed to stem the tide vs the outperforming Jpy as the headline pair ‘based’ just below 107.50 and ahead of the 30 DMA at 107.40, perhaps wary about huge barriers noted at 107.00. Usd/Cad broke out of its tight am range and above 1.2600, through 1.2620 resistance (100 DMA) and touched 1.2625 just in time for the NY cut and a 360 mn option expiry. Aud/Usd may also have had option interest capping price movement with 820 mn running off between 0.8050-60, while Nzd/Usd slipped back from 0.7300+ peaks as its US peer regained some composure. Cable remained relatively firm on above forecast UK inflation data, albeit unable to sustain gains above 1.3900 as Eur/Gbp edged towards 0.8900 and Eur/Usd inched above 1.2350. Lots more choppy trade in Usd/Zar as the ANC-Zuma stalemate rumbles on, and the Rand ultimately weakened (11.9700 vs 11.8800 at one stage) as the under pressure President resisted latest attempts to replace him with Ramaphosa. He is now due to respond to a recall and Wednesday’s Cabinet meet is postponed awaiting his reply.

Fixed Income update: paring gains/extending losses around the Wall Street open
content: Core EU bonds are drifting back further from am session and intraday peaks amidst typically hawkish musings from Fed’s Mester, and hedging risk bets on how Wall Street responds to rather mixed developments in global stocks since yesterday’s US close. UK Gilts continue to underperform after firmer than forecast inflation data, and just hit fresh lows for the day at 120.82, -32 ticks vs +29 ticks at best, while Bunds have retreated towards 158.00 from 158.44 at one stage. US Treasuries following suit after some minor PPI back data revisions (December readings tweaked up) and with CPI looming on Wednesday.

UBS Global Equities Flow Analysis (Week 6, 2018)
content:
GLOBAL EQUITIES:
- UBS saw a third week of inflows as volumes remained above average for a fifth consecutive week
- Bank says Inflows were driven by marginal buy skews across all regions

AMERICAS EQUITIES:
- UBS was net buyers of the Americas for a fourth week despite SPX closing the week down another 5.16%
- Bank notes volumes "unsurprisingly" took another leg higher
- UBS saw outflows from Consumer Staples sector, though saw inflows into the industrials sector
- Positive momentum in Tech & Comm, was noted, with the sector seeing a fourth week of inflows, though UBS says it was marginal

EMEA EQUITIES: 
- EMEA saw a second week of inflows, UBS says, following the rocky start to the year
- UBS were buyers of France, Germany and the Netherlands, sellers of Italy and the UK
- The bank saw strong buy skews in the consumer discretionary sector, as well as healthcare and industrials

APAC EQUITIES: 
- UBS saw inflows into APAC, though notes that volumes stayed below average for a seventh straight week
- the bank saw outflows in EM against inflows in DM, while consumer discretionary attracted the strongest buy skew of the sectors

subject: BofA Merrill Lynch February Fund Manager Survey notes investor anxiety but does not give the all clear to buy the dip
content:
- A record one-month jump in net % of investors indicating they have taken out protection against a sharp fall in equity markets in the next 3 months, at net -30% in February from net -50% in January
- Fund managers are rotating into cash and out of equities, reducing risk and cyclicality
- Average cash balance rises to 4.7% this month, up from 4.4% in January
- Allocation to equities fell to net 43% from net 55% overweight, the largest one-month decline in two years; allocation to bonds now at a record low of net 69% underweight
- Respondents indicate this S&P bull market will peak on average at 3100
- An inflation-induced bond crash (45%) remains at the top of the list of tail risks cited by investors; the top three are rounded out by a policy mistake by the Fed/ECB (18%) and market structure (13%)
- Long FAANG+BAT (26%), Short USD (20%) and Short Volatility (18%) are considered the most crowded trades
- A majority of investors surveyed (70%) now believe the global economy is in the “late cycle,” the highest level since January, 2008 
- Only 5% of fund managers surveyed say global interest rates will be lower in the next year; 80% expect them to rise
- A record net 24% of investors surveyed say global corporate balance sheets are overleveraged; the net percentage that would like to see companies return cash to shareholders remains close to 2009 lows

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European equities lower across the board after a mixed session overnight which saw the Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) hampered by the firmer JPY
content:
• European equities lower across the board after a mixed session overnight which saw the Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) hampered by the firmer JPY
  • In FX markets, USD softer against its peers. GBP firmer as UK inflation exceeds expectations (3.0% Y/Y vs. Exp. 2.9%)

Looking ahead, highlights include APIs, Japanese GDP and Fed’s Mester

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region cheered the continued rebound on Wall St. where all majors finished with firm gains and the S&P 500 posted its best 2-day performance in over 2 years. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) both opened higher in which mining-related sectors led in Australia, while Japanese stocks were initially outperformed buoyed as participants played catch up on return from holiday, although a firmer currency later saw gains wiped out. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1%) and Hang Seng (+1.3%) were jubilant heading closer to the Lunar New Year holidays and after the PBoC announced to lend CNY 393bln through the 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. Furthermore, there was a decline in money market rates in which the 1-week CNH HIBOR fell by the most so far in 2018, and the latest Chinese lending data also showed both New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing surged from prior. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar range-bound trade overnight in T-notes and although the BoJ were present in the market under its bond-buying program, this was kept at a reserved amount.

Japanese PM Abe said he is undecided on the next BoJ Governor, while Abe also stated that it is up to the BoJ to decide specific monetary policy measures and that he expects the BoJ to continue taking bold measures to achieve price stability. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations but announced CNY 393bln 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3247 (Prev. 6.3001)

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Jan) 12 vs. Exp. 10 (Prev. 11). (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Conditions (Jan) 19 (Prev. 13)

Japanese Currency Diplomat Asakawa said Japan will closely watch whether recent Yen movement will be speculative

CENTRAL BANK

EU/UK/US

UK CPI YY (Jan) 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 3.0%)

UK Core CPI YY (Jan) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)

UK CPI MM (Jan) -0.5% vs. Exp. -0.6% (Prev. 0.4%)

EQUITIES

European equities this morning opened on a negative foot (Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%) compared to the positive trading session in Asia (ex-Japan) and the US. Materials stand out as an outperforming sector amid the US infrastructure plans released yesterday whilst metals are extending gains: Gold (+0.4%), Silver (+0.1%), Copper (+0.8%). Telecoms underperform with BT (-1.2%) at the bottom of the FTSE 100 awaiting news from the Premier League TV rights.

FX

Yen strength the main overnight and early European theme, as Usd/Jpy breached last Friday’s 108.05 low to the downside before overcoming barrier and psychological support at 108.00 on its way to fresh 5 month lows around 107.55. Bids reportedly in the 107.70 area were also filled in pretty short order as risk aversion ratcheted higher, but it remains unclear whether heightened demand for the Jpy (and Chf to a lesser degree) was prompted by the Nikkei’s failure to maintain catch-up gains after Japan’s long holiday weekend or vice-versa. 107.50-45 next in sight for Usd/Jpy, with buying interest not really seen until the low 107.30 area (including last year’s 107.32 low), while cross demand is also rife as Gbp/Jpy falls below the 150.00 handle. GBP firmer after higher than expected inflation figures (3.0 vs. Exp. 2.9% Y/Y), however the rise had been short-lived, given that the headline figure had been in line with the BoE’s forecast. Nzd another noted beneficiary of US Dollar weakness as the Index loses grip of 90.000 again, with the Kiwi reclaiming 0.7300 status and in part also gaining some impetus from Aud underperformance amidst mixed sentiment readings overnight and RBA rhetoric – Aud/Usd above 0.7850, but Aud/Nzd back under 1.0800. Other Usd/G10 major pairings more contained, albeit still showing a generally softer Greenback, with Eur/Usd regaining 1.2300, Cable around 1.3850 eyeing UK inflation data and Usd/Cad sub-1.2600. Elsewhere, Usd/Zar still in focus and testing recent lows (currently circa 11.9000) ahead of an ANC briefing at 12GMT, with President Zuma still resisting efforts to remove him from office.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts and Short Sterling contracts declining to fresh Liffe session lows in wake of the headline inflation data beat that may not ultimately alter the near term BoE policy path, but clearly means that a May hike is more likely, especially if CPI is expected to overshoot target again. The core 10 year bond just reversed through 121.00 to a 120.97 intraday base (-17 ticks) and the 3 month strip is 1-3 ticks below parity. Even Bunds seem to have recoiled a bit in sympathy, but remain firmer on the day as the periphery trades down to new intraday lows ahead of Italian auctions (BTPs under pressure in particular predictably). USTs are still bid after yesterday’s sell-off and advance in yields with the long end marginally outperforming amidst curve re-flattening trades and outright RM buying.

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean Leader Kim said need to continue good atmosphere with South Korea and it’s important to liven up the warm climate of reconciliation & dialogue. (KCNA)

US VP Pence stated that strong new sanctions are coming soon on North Korea and that policy towards North Korea remains unchanged. (Newswires)

GLOBAL NEWS

South Africa's ANC party has to remove President Zuma as head of state, although President Zuma was earlier reported to have refused to resign and was also said to want a 3-month ‘notice period’ before resigning. (Newswires/Business Day) It was then later reported, that the ANC Secretary has gone to see Zuma to tell him the party has decided to dismiss him as head of state; according to sources. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

The theme continues for the oil markets, more supply is set to come from US shale producers. A report from the EIA yesterday noted that shale production for crude is to rise by 100k bbls in March, while another report this morning from the IEA expects US supply to grow more than demand in 2018, with US seen topping Russian production at year-end; as such both WTI and Brent have been pressured throughout the morning with the former briefly slipping below USD 59.00bbl. In metals markets, gold prices are near one-week highs amid the softer USD which has dictated a bulk of the price action for precious metals. Elsewhere, China have voiced concerns over US protectionism over steel, whilst aluminium prices have been pressured by building stockpiles.

IEA have upgraded their forecast for global oil demand growth to 1.4mln bpd in 2018 from 1.3mln, however they say Non-OPEC supply, led by US, which is likely to grow more than demand in 2018. (Newswires)

Iraq oil minister states that there is no current discussion over exiting supply cut agreement

Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that OPEC and Non-OPEC allies need to act very cautiously and avoid knee-jerk reactions in respect of new decisions

Libya's Waha oil refinery is undergoing maintenance to boost output capacity. (Newswires)

content: The UK STIR strip is flat to 1 tick adrift ahead of January inflation data despite the consensus for headline CPI to ease back below 3% amidst a 2.8%-3.1% forecast range. Latest comments from BoE’s McCaffery underscore the more hawkish guidance on rates, while the Bank has flagged the prospect of another overshoot in the near term, so confirmation of a modest slowdown will likely be viewed as a temporary dip. However, Gilts may derive external support from firmer Bunds and USTs on safe-haven grounds and resume Liffe on a firmer footing vs Monday’s 121.14 settlement, as its Eurozone counterpart edges a bit further into positive territory to 158.16 (+19 ticks) and testing the next resistance area between 158.17-21.

subject: Bunds: hugging the 158.00 handle in early cautious trade
content: A very tentative Eurex open, as the 10 year German debt future appears caught between the press higher in US Treasury and other core global bond yields on the one hand, and an abrupt turnaround in the Nikkei from decent catch-up gains in wake of Monday’s Japanese market holiday to a closing loss despite Wall Street managing to extend its recovery and equity rallies elsewhere in the Asia-Pac region. Bunds are sticking very close to parity as a result, and in relatively thin volumes of sub-10k lots within a 158.05-157.95 range vs yesterday’s 157.97 close. No Eurozone data of note scheduled today, but supply from Italy will be of interest as the countdown to March 4’s election continues.

US

EQUITIES: SPX +1.4% at 2656, DJI +1.7% at 24600, NDX +1.7% at 6524

Top sectors: Materials +2.1%, IT +1.7%, Energy +1.6%

Bottom sectors: Telecoms +0.5%Utilities +0.7%, Healthcare +0.9%

After last week’s slide, major stock indices continued the ‘recovery’, posting a second day of gains, in a further sign that last week’s selloff was technical/sentiment/position adjustment-related. Gains were broad-based, led by Apple and Boeing, while Cisco and American Express were higher on broker upgrades. Sector wise, materials and industrials were higher after Trump announced the much-awaited infrastructure plan, which will see the Federal government invest $200bln (which it is hoped will be boosted to $1.5trln after public-private partnerships), and the defence spending boost. Energy was tracking the crude complex higher, while financials benefited from higher yields. The analyst community continued to talk up the buy-the-dip potential of the market, after bears failed to force a close beneath the 200d MA on Friday. The VIX, meanwhile, slipped to the 25-handle, having surged above 40 last week.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region cheered the continued rebound on Wall St.
content:
• Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region cheered the continued rebound on Wall St.
  • FX was quiet, in which most majors held on to Monday’s gains against the greenback
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK CPI, APIs, Japanese GDP and Fed’s Mester

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region cheered the continued rebound on Wall St. where all majors finished with firm gains and the S&P 500 posted its best 2-day performance in over 2 years. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) both opened higher in which mining-related sectors led in Australia, while Japanese stocks were initially outperformed buoyed as participants played catch up on return from holiday, although a firmer currency later saw gains wiped out. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) and Hang Seng (+1.3%) were jubilant heading closer to the Lunar New Year holidays and after the PBoC announced to lend CNY 393bln through the 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. Furthermore, there was a decline in money market rates in which the 1-week CNH HIBOR fell by the most so far in 2018, and the latest Chinese lending data also showed both New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing surged from prior. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar range-bound trade overnight in T-notes and although the BoJ were present in the market under its bond-buying program, this was kept at a reserved amount.

Japanese PM Abe said he is undecided on the next BoJ Governor, while Abe also stated that it is up to the BoJ to decide specific monetary policy measures and that he expects the BoJ to continue taking bold measures to achieve price stability. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations but announced CNY 393bln 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3247 (Prev. 6.3001)
 

UK/EU

BoE’s McCafferty said the UK economy is holding up relatively well and it is likely rates will have to rise earlier than we thought late last year and noted it is too early to say whether the BoE will hike in May. (Newswires)

Japan's Ambassador to the UK Tsuruoka warned PM May that Japanese firms may leave UK if Brexit deal hits their profits. (Newswires)

FX

FX was quiet, in which most majors held on to Monday’s gains against the greenback. ZAR was in focus overnight and saw weakness on political uncertainty after reports the ruling ANC decided to recall President Zuma, who remained defiant and refused to resign. Elsewhere, AUD found mild support from an improvement in NAB business surveys, and USD/JPY was briefly pressured amid disappointment after PM Abe was said to be undecided on the next BoJ Governor. Furthermore, the weakness in USD/JPY was later exacerbated as the greenback continued to soften which saw USD/JPY slip below 108.50.

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Jan) 12 vs. Exp. 10 (Prev. 11). (Newswires)
Australian NAB Business Conditions (Jan) 19 (Prev. 13)

South Africa's ANC party has decided to either recall or remove President Zuma as head of state, although President Zuma was earlier reported to have refused to resign and was also said to want a 3-month ‘notice period’ before resigning. (Newswires/Business Day)

COMMODITIES

Commodities saw mild support overnight from a weaker greenback. This helped WTI recover from yesterday’s post-settlement pressure, which was triggered by EIA forecasts for increased shale production. Elsewhere, gold also benefitted from the weaker greenback, while copper conformed to the gains across the complex and in tandem with the heightened risk appetite in its largest consumer China.

EIA report stated that US Total Shale Regions Oil Production in March is forecast to increase by 111k BPD to 6.757mln BPD (Prev. 109k BPD increase in February). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean Leader Kim said need to continue good atmosphere with South Korea and it’s important to liven up the warm climate of reconciliation & dialogue. (KCNA).

US VP Pence stated that strong new sanctions are coming soon on North Korea and that policy towards North Korea remains unchanged. (Newswires)


US

Yields were slightly higher across the curve on Monday, with most of the action concentrated in the belly of the curve. The Tplex took its cue from continued ‘recovery’ in risk sentiment after last week, with 10s moving back to test 2.9% unsuccessfully, settling around 2.85%. Analysts were also citing concerns about the level of US deficits, and are mindful of inflation data, due Wednesday, for signs whether inflationary pressures are widespread, or fleeting/contained in certain areas. The US Treasury will also auction a new 30-year TIPS for $7bln, ahead of next week’s new 2s, 5s and 7s. US T-Notes settle 9 ticks lower at 120-25+.

content:
Asia stocks trade higher across the board as the region cheers the continued rebound on Wall St. where all majors finished with firm gains and the S&P 500 posted its best 2-day performance in over 2 years. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) are both higher with mining-related sectors leading in Australia, while Japanese stocks are buoyed as participants play catch up on return from holiday. Shanghai Comp. (+2.0%) and Hang Seng (+2.0%) are even more jubilant heading closer to the Lunar New Year holidays and after the PBoC announced to lend CNY 393bln through 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility, while the latest Chinese lending data also showed both New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing surged from prior.

FX markets are quiet with most majors holding on to Monday’s gains against the greenback. ZAR was in focus overnight and saw weakness on political uncertainty after reports the ruling ANC decided to recall President Zuma, who remained defiant and refused to resign. Elsewhere, AUD found brief support from an improvement in NAB business surveys, while USD/JPY was momentarily pressured on mild disappointment after PM Abe suggested that BoJ Governor Kuroda’s reappointment for a 2nd term is not yet a forgone conclusion as he was said to be undecided on the next BoJ Governor.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat amid similar range-bound trade in USTs and although the BoJ are present in the market under its bond-buying program, this was kept at a reserved amount.
